entities.description: A diagram comparing text-only RAG, layout segmented RAG, and BookRAG for complex document QA, demonstrating their strengths and weaknesses.
A query that is complex in nature, represented by a person icon in the diagram, serving as the initial point in the QA process.
The multi-page document used for QA, depicted as a stack of pages in the diagram.
An approach that involves plain text extraction, unstructured chunks, and fixed/graph retrieval using a vector/graph/tree.
The process of extracting plain text from the document using Optical Character Recognition.
The text chunks that have been extracted and processed without maintaining the document's layout or structure.
The index created from the unstructured text chunks, which can be vector-based, graph-based, or tree-based for retrieval.
The retrieval process that may be fixed or built on a graph structure to obtain relevant texts to the complex query.
The large language model used in text-only RAG and other comparisons that generates the answer based on the retrieved information.
A drawback of the text-only RAG in that it doesn't handle dependencies inherent in the document's structure.
This approach first conducts layout analysis and parsing before using a flattened vector index and fixed retrieval.
The analysis and parsing of the document's layout, which converts the complex multi-page document into a segmented form.
The indexing of the parsed document in a simplified, linear format to enable quicker retrieval of information.
A limit of layout segmented RAG that flattens the data and may lead to loss of complex interrelationships within the document.
A RAG method that utilizes hierarchical chunks and a bookindex and is agent-based to maintain the document's structural integrity.
The complex multi-page document converted into hierarchical chunks to preserve the structure's hierarchy.
An index that supports the structure-aware retrieval of the document's content, used in BookRAG.
The retrieval in BookRAG leverages an agent-based system to intelligently extract pertinent information for QA.
The outcome of using the BookRAG approach, producing answers that are accurate and grounded in the document's structure.
